awd_titl_txt: Examining Relationships Between Flipped Instruction and Students' Learning of Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
Instead of presenting new material in class and then assigning problems to be completed outside of class, flipped instruction involves students watching videos or reading new material outside of class and then completing their "homework" in class. Teachers' implementation of flipped instruction has increased dramatically in recent years, with more than two-thirds of teachers now reporting flipping a lesson, if not an entire course. Although popular media and philanthropic organizations have given a great deal of attention and financial support to flipped instruction, little is known about how teachers implement it and what benefits and drawbacks flipped instruction has in contrast with non-flipped instruction. This study can provide a basis for design research focused on developing effective materials and programs for flipped instruction in secondary mathematics. This design and development is already occurring at an increasing rate, but it is not yet informed by empirical evidence. This project will result in a framework for flipped instruction robust enough to be useful at a variety of grade levels and contexts. The framework will provide a better understanding of the relationships among various implementations of flipped instruction and student learning. These findings can inform teacher educators in better aligning their instruction to instructional formats that correlate with increased student learning outcomes. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of STEM innovations and approaches. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

Using mixed-methods techniques, the study will look at the nature of the activities and interactions occurring in mathematics classrooms and assess their quality so that the researchers may distinguish high-quality from low-quality univocal discourse, high-quality from low-quality dialogic discourse, and high cognitive demand from low cognitive demand tasks. Working in 40 algebra classrooms -- 20 implementing some form of flipped instruction and 20 serving as a non-flipped basis for comparison -- the project will address the following research questions using a correlational design and multilevel modeling techniques: RQ1. What are salient factors entailed in flipped instruction in secondary algebra? RQ2. What associations, if any, exist among factors entailed in teachers' implementation of flipped algebra instruction and students' learning of algebra as measured on a state-mandated end-of-course assessment and on a concept-of-variable inventory?

por.por_cntn:
The flipped instructional model is one in which teachers deliver content at home, typically via videos, and use class time to engage students in practice and/or application of that content. The use of flipped instruction, particularly in mathematics, has been increasing for the past decade. The goal of our project, the Flipped Math Study, was to to understand the components and factors of flipped instruction in secondary algebra classes and how they correlate with students? mathematical learning. Our project met this goal and provided substantial contributions to both researchers and practitioners in the field of mathematics instruction.

 

Two main research products emerged from the Flipped Math Study. The first of these products is the Flipped Math Instruction Observation Protocol. This protocol aids researchers in doing in-the-moment classroom observations in mathematics classrooms. The protocol captures several main aspects of teachers? mathematics lessons including the homework teachers assign (videos or problem sets), the ways in which teachers utilize classroom time with students, and the type of mathematics tasks teachers assign. For each of these aspects, we further distinguish their characteristics including the quality and/or content. This protocol is not only helpful for researchers to collect classroom observational data in real time, it is also for teachers and teacher educators to think through the design of their lessons, whether they are flipped or non-flipped.

 

The second product is the Flipped Mathematics Instruction Framework. Like the protocol, the framework captures components of mathematics lessons. It also allows for researchers to capture the sequencing of those components. The framework is useful in allowing for common language around frequent lesson components so that researchers can more easily discuss and compare characteristics of mathematics lessons and related outcomes. The framework has been particularly helpful for our research team in creating common profiles of teachers? lessons in both flipped and non-flipped classrooms. 

 

In addition to these two key research products, the project has generated research findings that can help inform subsequent studies of flipped and non-flipped mathematics instruction. During the course of our project we collected classroom observation and survey data from 22 flipped and 25 non-flipped classes. We also collected data (pre/posttest and survey data) from approximately 541 students (338 flipped and 203 non-flipped). In analyzing the student outcome data, we have found that while both flipped and non-flipped students had significant improvements on our pre/post test measures, the outcomes between the two groups differed significantly with the students in flipped classrooms scoring higher than those in non-flipped classrooms.  We also found a positive relationship between students? (both flipped and non-flipped) feelings about mathematics and their test scores. Moreover, students in non-flipped classes had significantly lower scores in terms of their feelings about mathematics.  We did not find significant differences between flipped and non-flipped students in relation to homework completion or student engagement. 

 

In addition to student outcome data, we also considered the teachers? use of class time and how it differed for flipped and non-flipped teachers. We found that flipped lessons had significantly more time allotted to student work time than non-flipped lessons. This is consistent with the teachers? motivation for flipping their lessons: to provide additional time for students to engage in mathematics tasks. 

 

Overall, our findings to date suggest that there may be some benefits to flipped instruction and those benefits might be in relation to the increased time for students to engage in mathematics tasks in class. Moreover, we found that in both flipped and non-flipped classrooms, student outcomes on procedural measures of algebra were higher than on conceptual measures. 

 

To date, our project has yielded numerous peer-reviewed articles and presentations for researchers and practitioners. Our findings in relation to teachers? use of flipped instruction and student learning outcomes can help to inform teacher professional development efforts and teachers? lesson design. In addition, these findings will help contribute to the relatively new and growing research base on flipped mathematics instruction and to provide a more nuanced approach to generating comparative findings between flipped and non-flipped instruction. Our hope is that these findings help to contribute to improved algebra instruction in both flipped and non-flipped classrooms, which may in turn improve student learning outcomes at this critical juncture of school mathematics.
